Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that St. Louis-based brokerage firm Edward Jones and the former head of its municipal underwriting desk agreed to settle charges that they overcharged customers in new municipal bonds sales.

Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P., a registered broker-dealer headquartered in St. Louis, Missouri, agreed to pay $75 million to settle allegations that it failed to adequately disclose revenue sharing payments that it received from a select group of mutual fund families that Edward Jones recommended to its customers.

Private Litigation Case Title: Thill v. Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P.
ELLIS v. EDWARD D. JONES & CO., L.P.
Notes: This case was the consolidation of four cases involving employees outside California.

Description: The California Attorney General announced a $7.5 million settlement with financial-services firm Edward Jones & Co. regarding the company's failure to inform its customers of its revenue-sharing agreements with various mutual-fund companies. In these revenue-sharing agreements, Edward Jones obtained payments from mutual fund companies in exchange for promoting their mutual funds to its clients.
Edward D. Jones agreed to pay $3.175 million to settle a lawsuit alleging it engaged in self-dealing in the administration of its 401(k) plan.
Private Litigation Case Title: Schultz et al v. Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P.  et al

Agency: Alaska Division of Banking and Securities

Description: Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. agreed to pay a $650,000 civil penalty and $850,000 to education funds to settle allegations that it failed to adequately disclose revenue sharing payments that it received from a select group of mutual fund families that Edward Jones recommended to its customers.

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
Pennsylvania Department of Banking and Securities

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered five firms to pay restitution estimated at more than $18 million, including interest, to affected customers for failing to waive mutual fund sales charges for eligible charitable organizations and retirement accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. of St. Louis $900,000 for its failure to timely deliver official statements to customers who purchased new-issue municipal securities and related supervisory and recordkeeping failures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $850,000 against four firms for failing to have adequate supervisory systems and procedures to identify opportunities for investors to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV), or without a front-end sales charge.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD has censured and fined Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. $300,000 for failing to disclose the yield-to-maturity on transaction confirmations issued to customers who sold municipal securities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered eight firms to pay fines totaling $310,000 and restitution to customers of $300,000 in connection with certain municipal bond trades where customers did not receive a fair price for their bonds, in violation of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB) rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: Edward D. Jones & Co. agreed to provide $34 million in compensation and forgiveness of $24 million in training costs paid by current and former African-American financial advisers who alleged they were given less-profitable assignments and excluded from professional development opportunities because of their race.
Private Litigation Case Title: Bland v. Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. et al
